snippet: The United States, largely because of poor oversight and loose financial controls, has sometimes inadvertently financed the very militants it is fighting.
abstract: Large contribution to $5 million ransom paid by Afghan officials to Al Qaeda in 2010 illustrates how Central Intelligence Agency and other United States organizations have inadvertently financed enemy militants; US officially refuses to pay ransoms, but some of the hundreds of billions it has spent over last decade of war has been siphoned off to enemy fighters, reflecting problems with poor oversight and loose financial controls.
lead_paragraph: The United States, largely because of poor oversight and loose financial controls, has sometimes inadvertently financed the very militants it is fighting.

headline.main: C.I.A. Cash Ended Up in Coffers of Al Qaeda
headline.print_headline: Cash From C.I.A. Ends Up as Part of Qaeda Funds

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
